Sebastian,"2014-05-12T19:55:59.61Z","Peaceful and charming scene","

This is the first 2014 set that I bought and also one of the few girly themed sets I have ever added to my collection.
The first thing I noticed about the new Disney Princess sets when I discovered them in the department store were the boxes whose upper top left and right edges were lowered. I do not
column2: know for what reason this has come about
column3: maybe the design department found the boxes to be more appealing this way and more likely to be &quot
column5: off the shelf. My major gripe with this is clearly the pricing.&nbsp
column6: All in all, you get a rather small set for 30,00 euros.&nbsp
column8: &nbsp
column9: &nbsp

column2: with many unusual parts that are somewhat uncommon to be found all in one single set. The most noteworthy here are probably the croissant, the three oars (one is a spare), a frog, two goblets, a light blue blossom piece, three of&nbsp
column3: the new fir pieces, transparent minifig heads, the big gazebo elements&nbsp
column4: and a dark violet basket/bag. There are also many small parts used for detailing.&nbsp
column6: hues prevail but there are some embedded particles of darker colours for contrasting which I liked a lot.

column2: nicely rearrangeable but I find there&nbsp

column8: de plaisance. However, the rather small but surprisingly heavy main portion includes some nice features like the telescope on the rooftop terrace, two vases and golden wine goblets. The upper part of the inside could have been a bit more substantial as one just looks at the hollow cylindric tower piece.

column1: The jetty is nicely done and was one of the incentives why I bought this set. Sometimes it'

column3: shade of yellow. The other micro build is a good attempt at a weeping willow given the small scale.

column1: Honestly, I do not really know to whom I should recommend this set apart from girls.

column1: This is a set, in essence, of segments. Some sections you can take to the bank, others make you want a refund. The disjointed feel might put some people off, however with a few other bits and pieces (specifically some of the Lego animal packs), this really is something. The target audience, if they&rsquo

column2: s the potential, to me, that really makes this set. I&#39
column3: ve contented myself in view of the issues that this is an early set in a theme that, hopefully, will be huge. There are so many (forgive me, but often same-y) Star Wars and City variants, I&#39
column4: ve got my fingers crossed that this takes off and becomes a staple with future sets getting new specific components and greater attention to (authentic) details that Lego is usually so awesome at.

column2: And, when no one is looking? I might just bob the boat about in the air, missing the magic of simpler times.

column1: ,TRUE,4,4,2,5,3 Odeinoichus","2017-05-20T18:24:45.597Z","Kiss the Girl... Seriously, no Eels in sight, perfect chance Eric.","
column8: >Set #41052 Ariel&rsquo
column9: s Magical Kiss:
column14: >Welcome to LEGO Disney Princess, where you can re-enact your favorite scenes from Disney Princess movies. Ariel&rsquo
column15: s Magical Kiss is no exception as it allows you to play out the great romantic scene from the movie. You have a lot to do here, as the set is quite large, the only real downside is that Sebastian was not included. Is this set worth tracking down if you missed it the first year of release? Read on to find out.

column8: >Box: LEGO Disney Princess has a really fun box design with an awesome dark pink colouring compared to the purple colours found on most LEGO Friends sets. The front of the box includes an awesome shot of the set in a fun scene and Ariel in her impressive looking green dress is drawn in the lower corner.

>The back showcases all of the features for playing that you can do with this set and of course shows you the group of LEGO Disney Princesses that were first offered in the initial waves, Ariel, Cinderella, Merida and Rapunzel.

>Instructions: This set features two numbered bags in one manual and the instructions are, as always, pretty fun. By which I mean that you can get some cross-promotional images in the back as well as a complete checklist for the wave. The instructions themselves are extremely easy to follow along with due to the numbered bag style of the build, however I should note that there are a lot of stickers for detailing on the main model of the set. Once again I would note that there is no protection and the sticker sheet can be damaged during the packing process depending on how it goes in.

>Like with many of these types of sets there are a lot of very good parts in brand new colours. Case in point this set starts off by including a pink LEGO rowboat, this is the first time I believe this piece has been made in this colour, usually you&rsquo
column9: d get them in brown, red or even blue.

column8: >You&rsquo
column9: ll also find a variety of grass and plant pieces, some nice teal pieces including what I think is some kind of upside down flower petal style piece&hellip
column10: I should perhaps try to include pictures of parts, but honestly I don&rsquo
column11: t like breaking down my sets to take images after they&rsquo
column12: ve been built. Er, so do forgive me for not knowing the proper name for this part.

column8: >Ariel: This version of Ariel uses the same head and hair piece, but now she&rsquo
column9: s wearing her pink dress. It isn&rsquo
column10: t the shimmering green dress that the artwork depicts, unfortunately, but the pink still looks stunning with nicely printed details for shimmering stars on the bottom of her dress and some nice side-printing for her hemline.

column8: >She includes a light purple bow in her hair and can swap it out for a small gold crown, though Ariel has never worn a crown once in my memory, but it&rsquo
column9: s nice for play options to switch it out.

column8: >Prince Eric: Eric has the distinction of being one of the first Disney Princes to be made in Mini-Doll form, he, Charming and Flynn Rider are the only three available to date and it&rsquo
column9: s nice to see him here.

column8: >His top captures the look of his white short-sleeved shirt quite nicely with a decent collar print around his neck and a good job of printing his belt/sash around her upper waist. The lower body is made with the standard Male Legs from LEGO Friends, which means he has back pockets in his pants, not entirely accurate as he doesn&rsquo
column9: t wear blue jeans, but it can be overlooked here because it&rsquo

column8: >Eric has no character specific accessories, but his hair piece is a nice solid black one with a very impressive level of sculpted detailing.

>Bag 1: Here you start with the two mini-dolls and then go on to build up the small dock, a tree covered in hanging vines, the rowboat and a small circular frog pond element. The tree is a really clever little build and I like what they did to make it resemble the tree from the movie although here it&rsquo
column9: s much smaller compared to the onscreen version.

column8: >The dock is also a nice little build with some fronds of greenery, possibly seaweed coming out of the ground on the water&rsquo
column9: s edge. Everything about this build is fun and there are no stickers here to cause issues.

column8: >Bag 2: This is a small palace area for the two Mini-Dolls to go and enjoy a romantic dinner, it&rsquo
column9: s built up with the most pieces from the set and features some great elements, there are a lot of stickers being used here though. Younger builders might need some help in placing the stickers here as they are on large rounded parts and need to be placed properly to line up across the two parts without actually going across two parts of course.

column8: >I enjoyed this build too, it looks great and works as a nice playset style build for Ariel and Eric.
>Hanging Tree: This is a very nice model, the use of a clear blue sloped brick to simulate water on the edge of the tree is a nice touch and the hanging vines isn&rsquo
column9: t a new idea, but here it is a very nice feature. The only issue is how small this is compared to what was seen in the movie, however it makes sense for this to be smaller here.

column8: >Boat &amp
column9: Dock: The boat is pink, and there is minimal building involved on the interior to make a nice seating area for both Mini-Dolls and a basket with a croissant in it for a little snack.

column8: >The dock area is built up quite nicely with a small bench area in the back with overhanging leaves to protect the occupant from rain. There&rsquo
column9: s a lot of foliage on the side of the dock as well, which adds a lot of nice detailing. The method for building the dock itself is pretty unique too, compared to similar docks from LEGO Pirates or Ninjago sets with similar docks. You can stand a mini-doll on two of the planks while the others are smooth 1x4 tiles.

column8: >Small Palace: This is built with an open-air garden type approach, the arches are used to wonderful effect here. The bulk of the interior area is a small dining area with a large table and two chairs, one with a Heart jewel on the top so that you know where Ariel should be sitting.
>There&rsquo
column9: s also a balcony built up on top with a telescope, there is no way to climb up to it, no ladder or steps, but it does give you more to do when playing with it besides just featuring the scene where Ariel and Eric share dinner together.

column8: >I really like how they made a small tower on top and the fancy looking lantern built with the teal blue parts, an astromech dome and the flower petal thing. The use of clear heads for flower vases in each window is very nice too, the gold pastry topping pieces work well for small details on the parapets of the little castle.
>The table setting includes two golden goblets and an apple and a banana in a pink dish.

>Frog Pond: This is a medium sized round blue plate with a bit of tan sloped pieces built up to make a rock-like structure and a few flowers floating on the water. On a jumper plate you can place a frog so that Ariel has one animal friend trying to encourage her in kissing Eric. A nameless frog is better than nothing I suppose.

>This set has a lot to offer, a great of potential for fans to build and play with Ariel and Eric re-enacting their favorite moments from the movie. It also has a lot of great detail work, which is quite common in most LEGO Friends/Disney Princess and Elves sets.
>This set to date is the only way to get Ariel as a human and Prince Eric, unless one of the Juniors sets has included them, though I haven&rsquo
column9: t seen it yet. Overall would I recommend this set? Yes, I would recommend this quite strongly, a lot of these sets from these Themes are loaded with impressive details and work great as display pieces for fans of Disney and playsets for the younger builders. This set unfortunately has since been retired, so you will need to find it on the secondary market by now. And now on to the next review from LEGO Disney Princess, someone learning about a Whole New World.
